NATIONAL HOUSING DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY : ROOFING SHEETS 1214/07 4. . .

Asked the Minister of Housing and Common Amenities : (a) Will she inform this House, - (i) the number of roofing sheets set apart for distribution in each district under the National Housing development Authority since 2nd April 2004 upto now; (ii) the number of families which have been provided with roofing sheets or housing aids in the digamadulla district ? (b) Will she submit to this House the list of names of the families to which the aforesaid aid has been provided ? (c) Will she state, - (i) whether she can give an assurance that the list consists of suitable persons selected in a proper manner; and (ii) the criteria used to select the recipients of housing aid ? (d) If not, why ?

asked the Minister, of Education, : (a) Is he aware that,- (i) Piliyandala Zonal Education Office is housed in a building which belongs to Piliyandala Central College; (ii) there is a need to develop the said school as the only National School in the area; (iii) there is a possibility of using the Zonal Edu-cation office premises for that purpose; and (iv) representations have been made in this re-spect by the past pupils associations of the school? (b) Will he admit that,-

(i) there is also a problem of protecting the files of the office as the zonal office building has become very old and dilapidated; (ii) the said building is in such a condition that it should be demolished and removed; and (iii) the said premises should be made available for the development of the school after pro-viding new premises for the zonal office? (c) will he state the steps that would be taken in this regard? (d) If not, why ?

(a) Will he inform this House the extent of the Lands that have been distributed under the distri-bution of lands to the middle class people from the lands which belong to the Land Reform Commission and the Government in the Gall district? (b) Will he submit that,-
(i) the names and the addresses of the owners of the aforesaid lands and the number of acres that have been given to them at Divisional Secretarys Division level;
(ii) the basis on which the aforesaid lands have been given and the relevant conditions; (iii) whether the Government has charged any money for the lands given to the middle class people; and
(iv) if any money has been charged, the amount of it? (c) will he state,- (i) whether the lands given to the middle class people have been transferred to other persons by them;

(ii) the names of transferors and transferees of the aforesaid lands and the names of the rele-vant lands; and, (iii) out of the distributed lands, the lands that have not brought under cultivation and their extents?

(d) will he take action to take over the lands that have not been brought under cultivation and are cov-ered with jungle and keep them as reserves or distribute such lands among the landless, if they are barren lands? (e) If not, why ?

() , ? asked the Minister of Construction and Engineering Ser-vices, : (a) Will he present this House separately, (i) the names of the projects that have been im-plemented and the projects that are being implemented by the State Development and Construction Corporation from 1995 to Octo-ber 2006; and (ii) the agreed value of each of the aforesaid pro-jects? (b) Will he inform this House, (i) the names of the projects which were started in the year 1995 and completed by November 2006; (ii) the dividends earned by the institution out of the projects completed as mentioned above; (iii) whether any arrears are due to the institution out of the aforesaid projects; (iv) if so, the amount of arrears; and (v) the actions taken so far to recover them? (c) Is he aware that it is this Corporation that has un-derkaken the contracts of building bridges which are being built across the Ging river in place of the bridges that were destroyed in the floods in 2003? (d) Will he state, (i) whether monies allocated for these bridges are used to offsed financial delays in other projects; (ii) if so, whether he would take action to pre-vent it; and (iii) whether he would take stepd to complete these bridges by the dates agreed? (e) If not, why?

PRESIDENTIAL SECRETARIAT May 08, 2007 Mr. Chandima Rasaputhra Chairman Airport and Aviation Services (Sri Lanka) Ltd My dear Chandima, Permit me to recall our conversation in regard to infusion of capital to Mihin Lanka Private Ltd. As you and I discussed, Mihin Lanka being the gov-ernments budget airline, requires further infusion of capital funds to surmount the initial difficulties of establishing it on a firm basis. As you may be aware, Mihin Lanka Private Ltd obtained its initial capital through a grant from Lankaputhra Bank where Lankaputhra Bank became a preferential shareholder. Similarly, I believe AASL being the organization, which manages the civilian airports in Sri Lanka, could have a considerable stake in Mihin Lanka Private Ltd. I suggest that the AASL becomes a preferential shareholder of Mihin Lanka by contributing Rs. 250 mn to its capi-tal. Please discuss with your Board and revert back to us as early as possible. Sgd/Lalith Weeratunga Secretary to the President Copy : CEO/Mihin Lanka privateLtd.

I am wondering whether it is worthwhile to talk of financial matters in Parliament, trying to protect public finance of this country when powers have been usurped or arrogated to herself by one Treasury representative to run the fi-nance of this country. Before that, for ten minutes -

Hon. Deputy Speaker, I would like to state here that there are certain actions that are inconsistent with the Constitution. I would like to take this opportunity to refer to the Appropriation Bills that have been passed in Par-

liament from the year 2000 onwards. Mr. Deputy Speaker, from the year 2000 up to 2005, this Parliament had the authority of maintaining the supreme privacy or the supreme right of controlling public finance. But, after President Rajapaksa became the Finance Minister in 2005, there has been a variation made to Section 6 of the Appropriation Act, No. 39 of 2005. Section 6 that was referred to by the Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe basically usurps the powers that are vested in the Constitution in one solitary person, the Secretary to the Treasury. Now, he is able at his own discretion to transfer any money allocated to any Head, Capital or Recurrent in nature without the consent of Parliament to any Programme un-der any other Head. That is deemed to have been brought to Parliament and its consent obtained. Mr. Dep-uty Speaker, either Mr. Speaker or you have basically given consent to these Appropriation Bills and we ask, how on earth have these been ratified? As I mentioned before I table* Annex 'C' which contains pages of Section 6 of the Appropriation Acts from 2003 - 2006. Sir, with your permission, I like it to be included in Hansard. Mr. Deputy Speaker, I like to read out to you the variations that have been brought into Section 6 of the Appropriation Acts from year 2005. It states, I quote: " Any money allocated to Recurrent Expenditure or Capital Expendi-ture under the 'Public Resources Management' .." That is what is important because that is the Head that allocates money which comes out of the consolidated fund. It further states, I quote: " Programme appearing under the Head 'Department of National Budget' specified in the First Schedule, may be transferred to any other Programme under any other Head in the Schedule by order of the Secre-tary to the Treasury or any other officer authorized by him. The money so transferred shall be deemed to have been covered by a supplementary estimate submitted by the appropriate Minister. Hon. Deputy Speaker, you seated on that Chair, how can you permit such a thing to take place in this House? You and I, we all have been robbed of an opportunity and today we are talking of a violation of the Constitution. I will be explaining that later in my speech, Hon. Deputy Speaker. But, this is the start. So, now how has it got to be done? Section 6 of the Appropriation Acts of 2005 and 2006, states that money allocated to the Public Re-sources Management Programme may be transferred to any other Programme and the money so transferred shall be deemed to have been covered by a supplementary esti-mate. Now, a supplementary estimate can be brought in only if there is an expenditure that has been voted in an Appropriation Bill. If there is no voting, even a rupee to a particular Head, how can the Treasury Secretary create a Head and transfer money to that? A supplementary ex-penditure is an expenditure that has been voted in. If it has not been voted in, how is he bringing it in? That is what the Hon. Leader of the Opposition mentioned.

How is Lankaputhra Development Bank getting money when it has not got a Head in the Appropriation Act ? How has money been brought into Mihin Air without the Object Code being specified in the Appropria-tion Act? Now, what are we talking of ? Are we not wasting our time if that is the case? So, I would greatly appreciate if you would look into this matter and follow up the final statements that were mentioned by the Hon. Leader of the Opposition, and appoint a separate Select Committee without wasting time hereafter because Par-liament can in just one day run through the Appropriation Bill when presented, pass it and thereafter the Secretary to the Treasury can do whatever he wants. Sir, I table* Annex 'D' which basically spells out the Department of National Budget, Head 240. It gives the allocation that we have voted through this Parliament which is Rs. 15 billion. Rupees 15,000 mil-lion is what is allocated. I am mentioning this before I get on to the Constitution. Prior to that, Parliament will be presented with the appropriation for the year 2008 which comes as the Appropriation Bill in 2007. This Clause will definitely be in that. That is why a responsible Leader who has governed this country mentioned it today rather than in November and then create a problem for the Budget. Now, be ready because the entire Budget is ultra vires and if that is the case we want this House to know that every single officer who has been involved in this has to be hauled for misuse of public finance. If the Hon. Sripathi Sooriyaarachchi on a trivial charge on hearsay was sent to jail for 70 or 80 days, imagine these officers who have arrogated powers unto themselves, where have they got to go? This is what we are saying. Now, the Hon. Bandula Gunawardane, when he was with us said that until and such time that the Secretary to the Treasury is there, this country can never prosper. Now that he is in the Government and in the Cabinet, we are questioning him as to whether he has been saying this. It is very clear. He has been referring to the Gover-nor of the Central Bank. Now that he is in the Govern-ment, does the truth submerge just because he has got to survive there? That is what I call hypocrisy. We have never been touching on those areas and questioning the Minister. But, now that he had asked us a question today, we need not show that we are impotent. We can show that we are ready to answer that. But, that has to be done in the manner that they were questioning when they were on this side. Hon. Deputy Speaker, now I table* Annex 'E' with your permission and I want it to be included in Hansard because this shows the allocation of funds that we have made through the Appropriation Act.

The Appropriation Act of 2006 shows that for the year 2007, we have voted Rs. 868 billion. Now, in this Rs. 868 billion, was Mihin Air in it? No. Then, how has the Secretary to the Treasury allocated Rs.250 million? I will table that document before too long and that is why I mentioned this figure. How on earth has he been able to transfer this? At least, does the Minister of Finance or the President of this country know as to how this operation took place? I am sure, not. That is the problem. It is one man who has been running amok the economy for the last 12 to 13 years. Is he basically taking this to the slaughter house? That is what we are asking. In the year 1994 when we handed the Government over to the Sri Lanka Freedom Party, the public debt per capita was Rs. 31,000 and the total was Rs. 504 billion. But, at this moment I am speaking in this august Assembly; the total public debt is Rs. 2783 billion with the per capita debt being Rs.141,000. So, that a significant increase has taken place owing to the mismanagement of the economy. When we were in the Government for two years, we strengthened the economy. But, we paid the price because we devel-oped the country forgetting the people. We say sorry to the people for that and we will never repeat that mistake. This time when we come, we know as to how we have got to develop the human resources first and then the country. But what we did, we did in good spirit. Now the Govern-ment that got the mandate to do otherwise is robbing the very people for whom they are supposed to be responsi-ble. Furthermore, they are robbing it through this august Assembly by taking over powers which are so sacrosanct to us. We have been elected because you cannot have 20 million people running a Government. We, the 225 who have been subordinated the role to run this have our rights protected through the Constitution. Now, the Constitution that has protected the rights and powers has been arro-gated to a few officials by one section and we, the Mem-bers of Parliament who have control over public finance are completely impotent. I, at this particular moment basi-cally indulge and seek assistance of the media to ensure that people are made aware of this. We, in the United National Party have always been saying that the economy comes first like when Bill Clinton got elected they said, Economy, stupid economy. That is what is happening to this country. Every problem that is there is due to the mismanagement of the economy. At this particular moment I would like to mention to this House that the monies allocated through Supplemen-tary Estimates and expended since 2002 of which this Parliament had not been informed, had taken place in a frivolous manner. In the year 2002, the total Supplemen-tary Estimates had gone up to Rupees seven billion. In the year 2003, it had been Rs. 22 billion. In the year 2004, it had been Rs. 38 billion. In the year 2005 there were Supplementary Estimates of Rs. 45 million, Rs. 58 million and Rs. 1.5 billion passed. Then in the year 2006, we had a Supplementary Estimate of Rs.109 billion and Rs. 2.75 billion. Then thereafter, just about a month and half ago, there was a Supplementary Estimate that was presented to this House to accommodate the 109

[ ] Ministers and that I think amounted to about Rs. 600 mil-lion. Those were the Supplementary Estimates that had come in. The Hon. Leader of the Opposition, when he was briefing us - my Colleague, the Hon. Kabir Hashim will speak about it later - said that when he was going into the matter of the Lankaputhra Development Bank and Mihin Air, he detected the manner in which money had been allocated. That is how the entire machinery came apart, revealing what the Treasury had done. Now I am tabling* Supplementary Allocation No. 215 of 2006 as Annex F, Head 801 - Department of National Budget; Programme 07 - Public Resource Management; Project 02 - Budgetary Support Services and Contingent Liabilities, allocating Rs.1.5 billion to Lankaputhra Development Bank. Have we, the Parliament, given the authority to this? No. Then how has this money been allocated? This letter has been signed by Mr. A.K.W. Mahendra for and on be-half of Director-General of National Budget. It states, I quote:

This transfer shall be deemed to have been covered by a supplemen-tary estimate submitted by the Minister of Finance and Planning in terms of Section 6 of the Appropriation Act No.39 of 2005. Now, Mr. Deputy Speaker, you would see the rele-vancy as to why I read out Section 6 of the Appropriation Act of 2005 because they are hiding and seeking refuge under that and trying to rob our rights in Parliament. I am asking the Deputy Minister of State Revenue and Finance, was he aware of this or was he part and parcel of the rob-bery of our rights in this House? If that is the case, he is also responsible. If not, why has this House not been in-formed about it? I am asking the Hon. Speaker as to how he had given his assent by signing the Appropriation Bill. We are asking as to how the Attorney-General permitted the Appropriation Bills of 2005 and 2006 to be presented in the House and ratified thereafter because it is his prime responsibility to ensure that Bills presented in this House are not repugnant to the Constitution. Before too long I will be stating as to why I say it is repugnant. At that mo-ment they will have to answer as to how this happened. Furthermore, I table* Annex G to show the allocation of shares of Lankaputhra Development Bank which go to individuals who are basically carrying this out. We are mystified to learn of these activities.
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, the time allotted to you was 25 minutes.
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Hon. Deputy Speaker, we are taking
( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Are you taking the Hon. Joseph Michael Pereras time?

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Yes. That is correct. TheHon. Kabir Hashim and I will be taking that time. Further I am tabling* Annex H, Supplementary Al-location No. 67 of 2007, Head 240 - Programme No. 02 - Development Activities; Project - Budgetary Support Services and Contingent Liabilities. There again Section 6 of the Appropriation Act, No.47 of 2006 is used and there is a Rs. 250 million transfer to Mihin Air. On the11th of November 2006, when the Hon. Anura Dissanayake from the JVP and I asked in this House as to how the funds had been given to Mihin Air, they said, "We will tell you how it was". But it was illegally done. We knew it was illegal. Once again in May, 2007 we did question as to how Mihin Air had been getting the money. But nothing was told. Now we have got to find it out ourselves and say, here is the rob-bery that has taken place. We are asking this Govern-ment, which is on one side increasing the price of petrol from Rs.67 per litre, the cost of fuel coming into the har-bour and selling it at Rs. 120 per litre by taking Rs.60 as their taxes, is this not villainy? Sir, I table* Annex 'I', which is a letter from Sajin Gunawardena. He had the audacity to write to Parliament and say that he is having a press conference and for us to attend that to see what is going on at Mihin Air. This is the type of gentlemen who run the economy in a manner as if they are running their private property. This is basically why we are questioning as to who gives them such authority. Such people were not appointees of Parliament. The Hon. Mangala Samaraweera mentioned that he was never a party to appoint him as a Director. Now he has been appointed and he is taking the economy to task. So we are asking at this particular moment how such things have happened? The other thing is, when the Budget for the year 2008 is presented the Government would come with sugar-coated things. The Secretary to the Treasury who basi-cally handles 99 per cent of the operation will suddenly come, and like taking a rabbit out of a magic box, will say that I am giving a surplus budget this time. So we, in Parliament will be mystified not knowing that our own powers have been arrogated to himself. He will come saying, here is a surplus budget and then give a deficit budget at the end of the budget session. Now this is what is going on.

The Deputy Minister of Finance is powerless today. He is only voted to come and answer questions and get heated responses from us. So we are asking, is this same mess going to be continued in the Appropriation Bill of 2008 that is to be presented within the next two weeks? What is the remedial action? Now that we have warned the necessary people that this is an ultra vires budget, we are asking as to what legal steps will be taken on this particular matter. If people can go back to history and say that the UNP gave Rs. 220 billion as tax amnesty and if they could not collect even Rs. 500 million, that is half a billion, what are they doing in this instance? Why are they so silent and where is the good governance? We are asking on this particular basis, on this ultra vires act, how on earth are we to go forward? Mr. Deputy speaker, I am getting back to the legality become are, as the United National Party Say from this moment onwards that there is no point talking in this House on finance matters. Our powers have been arro-gated and we have been basically brought down next to nothing. So on that score, this Budget remains to be ultra vires and from now onwards we are telling the people that they can even ask for tax refunds from the Government. Sir, now I refer to Article 4 of the Constitution. It says, I quote : "The Sovereignty of the People shall be exercised and enjoyed in the following manner : - (a) the legislative power of the People shall be exercised by Parlia-ment, consisting of elected representatives of the People and by the People at a Referendum : (b) the executive power of the People, including the defence of Sri Lanka, shall be exercised by the President ........." Further, even the fundamental rights of maintaining public finance is vested in the Parliament. Then Article No.76. (1) says, I quote : "Parliament shall not abdicate or in any manner alienate its legisla-tive power, and shall not set up any authority with any legislative power." This is delegation of the legislative power. Now what have we done? We have done exactly what basically we have been called upon not to do. Further, Article 148 says, I quote : "Parliament shall have full control over public finance. No tax, rate or any other levy shall be imposed by any local authority or any other public authority, except by or under the authority of a law passed by Parliament or of any existing law." Article 149(1) says, I quote: "The funds of the Republic not allocated by law to specific pur-poses shall form one Consolidated Fund into which shall be paid the produce of all taxes, imposts, rates and duties and all other revenues and receipts of the Republic not allocated to specific purposes."

Now, Mr. Deputy Speaker, see the relevance of the Constitution vis-a-vis to where we are placed in. Hon. Deputy Speaker, you are at the moment on top of a pow-der keg which is about to explode. Today, the HSBC, that the Government is trying to lure to take money will think how on earth they are going to collect money from the Government when the Government is illegally constituted to misuse public finance in this country. Now, Sir, I refer to Article 152 which states, I quote: No Bill or motion, authorizing the disposal of, or the imposition of charges upon, the ConsolidatedFund or other funds of the Republic, or the imposition of any tax or the repeal, augmentation or reduction of any tax for the time being in force shall be introduced in Parliament except by a Minister, and unless such Billor motion has been approved either by the Cabinet of Ministers or in such manneras the Cabinet of Ministers may authorize. Now we ask, has this taken place? In that case, why are we wasting time in Parliament? Then, Article 75 (a) states, I quote: Parliament shall have power to make laws, including laws having retrospective effect and repealing or amending any provision of the Constitution, or adding any provision to the Constitution : Provided that Parliament shall not make any law - (a) suspending the operation of the Constitution or any part thereof, or (b) repealing the Constitution as a whole unless such law also enacts a new Constitution to replace it. Why I mention this is because we have amended the Constitution without we knowing about it. If that is the case, we have got to go to the very premise and in that case what are we talking of? Then, coming back to Arti-cle 150 (2) with regard to withdrawal of sums from Con-solidated Fund, it states, I quote: No such warrant shall be issued unless the sum has by resolution of Parliament or by any law been granted for specified public services for the financial year during which the withdrawal is to take place or is otherwise lawfully, charged on the Consolidated Fund. So, Sir, I am once again questioning because you are part and parcel of the machinery in Parliament. The Hon. Speaker, the Deputy Chairman of Committees and you have got the approval from the Attorney-General, signed and sealed it off and now we are saying that this is against the Constitution. I also refer to Article 84 (1) which states what has got to be done in regard to Bills inconsistent with the Constitution. How has the Attorney-General given the consent for the Appropriation Bill of 2005 and 2006 to be sent to Par-liament when it is inconsistent with the Constitution? , , , . This is the problem we are faced with . Article 84(1) states, I quote: A Bill which is not for the amendment of any provision of the Constitution or for the repeal and replacement of the Constitution, but

which is inconsistent with any provision of the Constitution may be placed on the Order Paper of Parliament without complying with the requirements of paragraph (1) or paragraph (2) of Article 82. Sir, going on further, Article 82 (1) states, I quote: No Bill for the amendment of any provision of the Constitution shall be placed on the Order Paper of Parliament, unless the provision to be repealed, altered or added, and consequential amendments, if any, are expressly specified in the Bill and is described in the long title thereof as being an Act for the amendment of the Constitution. ( ) (The Deputy Speaker) Hon. Member, I am sorry, you have now ex-hausted the extended time. ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) No, I have got 20 minutes more. The Hon. Joseph Micheal Perera - ( ) (The Deputy Speaker) No, 15 fifteen minutes because we lost 75 minutes of the total time. ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Well, I will take only five minutes more. Sir, due to lack of time I also table* the Determination of the Supreme Court on the Nineteenth Amendment to the Constitution. It states that powers vested in one organ of the Government cannot be usurped by any other, that is the Executive, Legislature and the Judiciary. ( ) (The Hon. Kabir Hashim) You may take five minutes from my time. ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Thank you very much. This is not a Debate that will finish today because after this there is no point in having Parliament as we have lost our powers. It is ultra vires. Anybody can go before the Supreme Court and if one basically places all the facts, the Court will have to say that this is against the Constitution. So, on that particular score, the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act that was brought into Parliament in order to ensure that such nonsense does not take place, has also been violated. Officers who contravene this Act will be liable for a punishment of not less than 20 years jail.

Now, Sections 13 and 15 of the Fiscal Manage-ment (Responsibility) Act makes it mandatory that certain specified data be provided to Parliament. But none of them have been provided except for a mere statement for the year 2004 given on 10th of June 2005, for the year 2005 given on 23rd of May 2006, and for the financial year 2006, they have pre-sented a document on 5th of August 2007. But it has no relevance to the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act. So, it has once again superfi-cially given certain information which is only fool-ing the people. They think that there are a pack of idiots in this House. That is what the officials in this country think, not all officials, just one or two think that they know everything. This is the situation. The people of this country will thank the Leader of the Opposition for highlighting these things. Up to now they ask, what the Opposition is doing? We are confronted with a monolithic Executive Presidency and we are fighting to take out nail after nail from that and now asking where this responsibility is. Now you know what is going on. Sir, Section 15 of the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act is completely misleading. In the national Budget for the year 2006, there have been 11,283 transactions that have taken place without we, the Parliament knowing it. 2006 11,283 . .

Sir, I table* a document titled "Financial Procedure" that refers to the case Wanigasekera Vs the State in which for mere misrepresentation of Rs. 600,000 they were reprimanded. Hon. Deputy Speaker, all we can say is, all this is irrelevant. Today, people are dying of starvation; the economy is in such a mess that the Government is unable to provide a satisfactory answer to that. So, we are trying to point out what the answer should be.

Re. Reference to Mahin Lanka on 360 Program conducted by Derana TV.

Reference the above program where the undersigned responded and requested that a opportunity to be provided to the Board of Directors of Mihin Lanka to answer any questions that the Hon. Member may have on the setting up and functioning of Mihin Lanka. During the course of the conversa-tion that took place the Hon. Member of Parliament conveyed to the undersigned that it is not the functioning of the company or Act (translated to English as the program was in Sinhala) that he is against but the policy decision that was taken to set up a new air line.

We wish to inform you that we will be organising a Press Conference shortly where we will submit to the members of the press and general public details pertaining to the setting up and performance of Mihin Lanka from inception to date. Accordingly we take this opportunity to invite the Hon. Member to be present and to pose any and all questions etc., that you may want to. We will inform in the immediate future the date, time and venue.
Thanking you Yours faithfully Sajin de Vass Gunawardena Chief Executive Officer
